subNodes.conversationText: <FirstName> recognized the boy <he/she>'d met earlier, the woodcutter's son. He was chopping wood. This place looked to be his home. <He/She> saw a cabin, stacks of wood, and a number of felled trees, but no sign of the woodcutter himself.
The boy heard the crunching of leaves and looked up at the witch, startled. Something startled Pharaoh, too. He darted from the witch's shoulder up to a very high branch in a pine.
"Oh, it's you again." The woodcutter's son relaxed. "Why did you come here?"
"Is your father here? I'd like to see what he knows about these woods."
"Father? No. He's away." The boy returned to chopping wood.
He wiped sweat from his brow and shrugged. "I don't know."
"Hmm. I'm looking for someone else, too. I was told you know where he is."
He wiped sweat from his brow and shrugged. "I don't know."
"Hmm. I'm looking for someone else, too. I was told you know where he is."
"If I see him," he said, "I'll tell him you were looking for him."
"Hmm. I'm looking for someone else, too. I was told you know where he is."
The boy continued his work and didn't acknowledge the remark.
"Hmm. I'm looking for someone else, too. I was told you know where he is."
"Please do," said the young witch, though <he/she> didn't really know how this could help <him/her>.
The boy continued his work and didn't acknowledge the remark.
"Look around if you want. There isn't much to see here, though."
"Father? No. He's away." The boy returned to chopping wood.
"I'm looking for someone, and I was told you know where he is."
"I'm looking for someone, and I was told you know where he is."

"Malkin..."

The boy looked confused. He rested his axe against a pile of wood and rubbed his temples.
"I don't know anyone by that name, but I think I've heard it before."
"I can take you to where I heard it."

Off the path leading to the woodcutters hut was another, narrower path that <FirstName> had not seen before. They followed it for a half hour through stands of ilex and low, scrubby trees until they came to a slight hill.

At the top of the hill grew a tree all alone. Its leaves were young and yellowish green, like leaves in spring. It bent, and the direction the wind blew could be read in its bending. Strange blue flowers grew at its base. Stranger still, the sedge that grew in its shadow had blades as red as blood.
"I don't know anyone by that name, but I think I've heard it before."
There was a question in the boy's look.

Off the path leading to the woodcutters hut was another, narrower path that <FirstName> had not seen before. They followed it for a half hour through stands of ilex and low, scrubby trees until they came to a slight hill.
"Yes. Is your father here? I thought I might talk to him."
"Father? No. He's away." The boy returned to chopping wood.
"News?" The boy shook his head and went back to work.
"I'm looking for someone, and I was told you know where he is."
The witch gave the boy a taste of his own medicine and said nothing.
[Woodcraft] "I'm interested in trading for some of those arrows you make."

"All right. I can always use herbs."

The boy showed <him/her> an array of different arrows. They were all made very well. More surprisingly, they were enchanted.
"These have a touch of witchcraft, you know."
"Do they?" The boy looked troubled, but then the look passed.
"What kind of arrow do you want?"
<FirstName> exchanged some bishop's satchel for a quiver of goose-fletched arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some bishop's satchel for a quiver of goose-fletched arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some hagmallow for acid arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some wightbonnet for icy arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some royal dandywill for flaming arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some pig onion for lightning arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some hagmallow for acid arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some wightbonnet for icy arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some royal dandywill for flaming arrows.
<FirstName> exchanged some pig onion for lightning arrows.
"On second thought, maybe I'll come back later."
"These have a touch of witchcraft, you know."
"What kind of arrow do you want?"

actions.a_parameter_1: The woodcutter's son will give you magical arrows in exchange for certain plants. The plants he is interested in are bishop's satchel, hagmallow, wightbonnet, royal dandywill, and pig onion.

subNodes.conversationText: The woodcutter's son was whittling something.
The boy was carving a little dog.
